review.title: Evaluating Temporal Graphs Built from Texts via Transitive Reduction
review.abstract: Temporal information has been the focus of recent attention in information extraction, leading to some standardization effort, in particular for the task of relating events in a text. This task raises the problem of comparing two annotations of a given text, because relations between events in a story are intrinsically interdependent and cannot be evaluated separately. A proper evaluation measure is also crucial in the context of a machine learning approach to the problem. Finding a common comparison referent at the text level is not obvious, and we argue here in favor of a shift from event-based measures to measures on a unique textual object, a minimal underlying temporal graph, or more formally the transitive reduction of the graph of relations between event boundaries. We support it by an investigation of its properties on synthetic data and on a well-know temporal corpus.

metadata.title: Evaluating Temporal Graphs Built from Texts via Transitive Reduction

sections.text: This task raises the problem of comparing two annotations of a given text, since the relationships between events in a story are intrinsically interdependent and cannot be evaluated separately. An appropriate evaluation quantity is also critical to the problem in the context of a machine learning approach. Finding a common comparator at the text level is not obvious, and we are advocating a shift from event-based measures to actions on a unique text object, a minimal underlying timeframe, or formally for the transitive reduction of the graph of relations between event boundaries. We support it by examining its properties on synthetic data and on a well-known timeframe.

sections.heading: 2.1 Temporal Closure
sections.text: Temporary closure is an inferential closure mechanism consisting of known pairs of temporal relationships to the previous relationships in order to maintain new relationships, up to a fixed point. For example, if A bB and C dB, then there are exceptions, as in the work of Mani et al. (2006) and Mani et al. sections.heading: 2.2 Time Point Algebra and Convex Relations
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to move in a direction in which they are able, in which they want to move, and in which they are able, in which they want to move, and in which they are able to move.

sections.heading: 2.3 Strict and Relaxed Recall and Precision
sections.text: In general, both humans and systems can assign disjunctions of atomic relationships between two events (i.e. A bB, A mB), directly or indirectly (after saturation), which is a way to reduce uncertainty, even if the exact relationship between two events is not known. The presence of disjunctions raises the question of how to evaluate relationships that are only partially correct, such as A bB, A mB and vice versa. In response to this problem, various variations of common precision and callback measures are proposed. A strict measure counts only exact match as a success and will, for example, 0 points for the latter example. However, it can be argued that a rating measure should better take into account "close matches." For example, we assume that the gold standard relationship between A and B is A bB A bB. If the system chooses disjunction A bB, SB and SB, it must be rewarded less than A B or nothing at all.

sections.heading: 2.4 Relative Importance of Relations
sections.text: As shown above, a temporal closure is necessary in order to be able to correctly compare two temporal diagrams, but in a temporal diagram relationships do not have the same meaning. Applying basic memory and precision results (either strict or relaxed) to closed temporal diagrams is not enough. Consider the very simple diagram examples of Figure 6, in which the first graph K is the gold standard. S1 contains only two relationships, versus six in K. But it seems unfair to consider a memory value of 26, since adding only one relationship (B bC) would be sufficient to deduce all the others. An intuitive reminder would be about 23. What matters here is how many relationships are missing to restore the entire annotation graph − But even if we assume that we have a way to clearly distinguish "significant" relationships (solid lines in K) from "minor" (ductible) relationships (dashed lines in S2), then it is not enough to distinguish other relationships, because S2 is not enough to find them in SD.

sections.heading: 2.5 “Minimal” Graphs
sections.text: As I said, a good but insufficient way to deal with the relative importance of graph relationships would be to work on what we call "significant" relationships or "minimal graphs." We consider a temporal graph to be a "minimal graph" of a graph G, if: 4. However, the MUC metrics contain other problems that were later addressed by the metrics B3 and CEAF, but which have no relevance to the evaluation of a temporal graph. The main problem is the tendency to favor the prediction of a co-reference link for each pair of mentions; this has no counterpart in the temporal case, since event pairs can be linked to other relationships and are associated with other inferential properties, as opposed to just one equivalence relationship. Its temporal closure leads to the same temporal information as G.2. No relationship can be removed from this graph without breaking the first property.

sections.heading: 2.6 Behavior of Existing Metrics
sections.text: As stated in the work of Tannier and Muller (2008), a recall is expected to decrease in a linear manner as the amount of information decreases. Otherwise, evaluation yardsticks might not exhibit gradual changes that make comparisons of models difficult. Furthermore, we expect the amount of information to grow roughly proportional to the number of events in the text. This behavior can be evaluated by comparing a given comment with the same remark that excludes some of the time information. Figure 7 shows how recalls develop when relationships are removed from a time chart until no relationships exist. It shows the different values of a strict recall according to the ratio of the relationships held in the chart, as well as the ideal y = x line. This can be viewed as an illustration of the consequences of an annotator "forgetting" some relationships in order to comment on some relationships, in relation to an ideal reference point.

sections.heading: 3. Proposed New Metric
sections.text: Many measures of similarity exist between two graphs once a many-to-many agreement has been found between the nodes of both graphs (Sorlin, 2006). Node matching, which is a major problem in graph comparisons in general, is not difficult in our case, since we take into account that both graphs comment on the same events or expressions. A traditional similarity function between two graphs is the following (Sorlin, 2006): sim (K, G) = f (K to G) − g (splits (m)) f (K-G), where KumG is the set of relationships that both graphs share according to the node matching function m, K-G the union between node and G relations, and splits (m) the number of node splits imposed by the coincidence to obtain one graph with the other (see examples later). Functions f and g depend on the types of the graph, and we have different symmetry and application metrics, but these two are not suitable metrics below the two.

sections.heading: 3.1 Transitive Reduction of Endpoint Graph
sections.text: To solve the problem of finding minimal graphs and taking into account the relative importance of relationships, we take inspiration from the work of Dubois and Schwer (2000) in two main ideas. Firstly, graphs are saturated (i.e. the temporal closure is applied) and are converted into endpoint graphs. < secondly, two nodes connected by an equality relationship are fused together (this will help to guarantee the uniqueness of the graph, see below), a useful process to point-based graphs (van Beek, 1992). Figure 8 represents the graph of Figure 3 after this transformation, i.e. the resulting point graph is saturated by defining the composition of the event relationships in Allen's algebra graph, the graph we are looking at is constructed from "convex" annotations, i.e. there can be no "< or" relationship between two points "> because we can maintain relationships without losing and stranstranstranstranstranstranged information.

sections.heading: 3.2 Temporal Recall and Precision
sections.text: As we have shown in Section 2.4, minor relationships should still be rewarded if they are not redundant in the evaluated diagram. However, they must have a lower weight. Minor relationships should only be taken into account in the time call and not in the precision. The reason for this is that the call evaluates the proportion of reference relationships found by the system and this system can find some minor relationships without the larger relationships they have produced in the reference being redundant by definition (see B b D in Example S4, Figure 6). On the contrary, precision evaluates the proportion of system relationships located in the reference diagram and minor (i.e. derivable) relationships found by the system are redundant by definition. Our callable measure is then a combination of two values. Since K is the reference diagram and G the evaluated diagram: • The large time call is the rate of the reference relationships of major relationships being found in the time call.

sections.heading: 3.3 Notations
sections.text: Note: • G and K the event graphs, K the reference (key); • Gpt and Kpt the associated endpoint graphs, in which equivalent points are merged. • (N, R) the set of nodes and relationships of the graph G and mutatis mutandis for the others. • In the examples, only non-trivial relationships are listed. Trivial relationships are those that concern two points of the same interval. For example, A1 < A2 in Figure 8 is trivial and therefore not taken into account. In all the figures, trivial relationships are dashed grey lines. Non-trivial relationships and the node list are sufficient to find the complete graph. • The temporal closure of G is determined as G. • The temporary reduction of G is now noted as Gmaj.

sections.heading: 3.4 Temporal Recall and Precision
sections.text: Our new measures of temporal memory and precision are based on the terms defined above. With regard to the memory value, we have shown that it was important to distinguish "large" relationships, i.e. relationships that belong to the minimal graph, from the other "small" relationships. Therefore, we propose to calculate the memory value in two steps.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 SYNTHESIS
sections.text: The evaluation of an interval diagram G against a gold reference K is achieved by the following steps: 1. Perform a transitive closure on both G and K.2. Convert both diagrams into endpoint diagrams. 3. Merge equality relationships into individual nodes. 4. Perform a transitive reduction. 5. Calculate values of time retrieval and precision. 7. http: / / www.irit.fr / ~ Philippe.Muller / resources.htmlThe most expensive operation here is the first and is common in the standard evaluation method; its time is in O (| N | 3) at worst, with the algorithm 1 page 379, N being the event set of the largest diagram between G and K. The other is directly linear in the number of relationships of the diagram (conversion to endpoints, merging of equities in the closed diagram), or even worse, in O | 2, the total diagram for both the composition and the composition of the relationship (i.e., the first composition and the composition) is the difference of the diagram, not the first step.

However, even if three relationships are present, three more are still missing (the same number of missing relationships as if the graph had no connection at all). Furthermore, the fact that all minor relationships do not receive a better value than a larger relationship is the condition for not exceeding the limits. Finally, this case is rare and does not affect the general behavior of the metric.

sections.heading: 4. First Simple Case: Non-Disjunctive Allen Relations
sections.text: Consider the example graph K1 of Allen's non-disjunctive relationships (see also the graph in Figure 12): K1 = A B C D E FA s bi b s bB bi m s mC b bD f eE fiThe conversion into relationships between endpoints results in the following graph in which an event A is split into A1 and A2. Edges are not labeled because only the relationship "<" is considered at this point.Note that merging identical nodes is not equivalent to labeling arcs with "=," since in the latter case the minimal graph would no longer be unique. For example, the necessary choice between A1 < A2, B1 < A2 < A2 < A2 and E1 < A2 would result in three equal but different graphs. sections.heading: 5. Disjunctive Convex Relations
sections.text: We now apply the metric to sets of convex relationships. Convex relationships are a series of relationships that are conceptual neighbors, i.e. they encode relationships that may be vague, but at which intervals endpoints can only be in convex subsets of the timeline (see Section 2.2). The structure of the minimum diagram follows the same procedure as described above (transitive reduction).The measurements do not differ at all when we choose a strict point system (see Section 2.3).But in a relaxed scheme with disjunctions, it is necessary to use a weighting method; an answer is no longer assigned to a binary value (0 or 1), but to one of the values in Table 3, for example, in a manner similar to TempEval (Verhagen et al., 2007).As shown in this table, the relaxed measure has an effect on false values and on vltltltc (a relationship can be half a point), but also on conversion and split values (where half points are also possible).

sections.heading: 6. Experiments
sections.text: We are pushing for a change in the measurement scales of the temporal annotations graph was motivated at the beginning of the paper by a few examples in which we show some undesirable side effects of the Common Evaluation Procedures. We will now present a more thorough methodology aimed at evaluating the evaluation process itself. We have used two types of data for this purpose. Obviously, we can test and compare actions against the freely available temporal annotations provided in the TimeBank corpus. We are also introducing a set of artificially constructed temporal graphs on which we can control a few relevant parameters. TimeBank annotations are more heterogeneous because human annotators make mistakes or introduce inconsistencies, creating appropriate noise. We also wanted to test other aspects of temporal annotations that are easier to create from scratch.

sections.heading: 6.1 Artificial Graphs
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it is only a matter of time before there is a result, until there is a result.

sections.heading: 6.2 TimeBank Corpus
sections.text: Before presenting the results of our evaluations of the real annotated data of the TimeBank corpus, we show some features of the time charts induced by the annotations. This helps to understand some of the differences between the behavior we observe on the synthetic time charts and the more ecological one.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 ANALYSIS OF THE TIMEBANK CORPUS
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it will only be once before there is such a process, in which there is such a process.

sections.heading: 6.2.2 MEASURES ON TIMEBANK
sections.text: This year it is so far that it only takes a few days to reach an agreement.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: It remains unclear whether this could be an acceptable way of presenting temporal information to humans, or how the resulting minimal graphs could be meaningfully translated into interval relationships. We are arguing here for benchmarks that are free from some of the biases inherent in the commonly used Allen-based time graphs closures comparisons and are unique in the cases considered. We have shown empirically that the behavior of this type of measurement is appropriate to the goals we had in mind. We are not arguing that ordering interval endpoints should be considered as the human-provided annotation, only that the translation is possible and useful. It remains unclear whether this could also be an acceptable way of presenting temporal information to humans, or how the resulting minimal graphs could be meaningfully translated into interval relationships.

sections.heading: 8. Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work has benefited from tremendously helpful feedback from several colleagues, mainly Pierre Zweigenbaum and Pascal Denis, as well as Nicholas Asher. Pascal Denis also contributed to the development of the temporal tools used in this work and allowed us to use some of the results of the temporal relationship identification system he developed with Philippe Muller. We also thank Michel Gagnon, who long ago proposed comparing a remark with a demoted version of himself as an assessment of a measure.

referenceMentions.context: Temporal processing of texts is a somewhat recent field from a methodological point of view, even though temporal semantics has a long tradition, dating back at least to the 1940’s (Reichenbach, 1947).

While theoretical and formal linguistic approaches to temporal interpretation at the discourse level have been very active in the late 1980s and early 1990s (Kamp & Reyle, 1993; Asher & Lascarides, 1993; Steedman, 1995; Webber, 1988), empirical approaches were less frequent, and very few natural language processing systems were evaluated beyond a few instances (Grover, Hitzeman, & Moens, 1995; Kameyama, Passonneau, & Poesio, 1993; Passonneau, 1988; Song & Cohen, 1991).

While theoretical and formal linguistic approaches to temporal interpretation at the discourse level have been very active in the late 1980s and early 1990s (Kamp & Reyle, 1993; Asher & Lascarides, 1993; Steedman, 1995; Webber, 1988), empirical approaches were less frequent, and very few natural language processing systems were evaluated beyond a few instances (Grover, Hitzeman, & Moens, 1995; Kameyama, Passonneau, & Poesio, 1993; Passonneau, 1988; Song & Cohen, 1991).

While theoretical and formal linguistic approaches to temporal interpretation at the discourse level have been very active in the late 1980s and early 1990s (Kamp & Reyle, 1993; Asher & Lascarides, 1993; Steedman, 1995; Webber, 1988), empirical approaches were less frequent, and very few natural language processing systems were evaluated beyond a few instances (Grover, Hitzeman, & Moens, 1995; Kameyama, Passonneau, & Poesio, 1993; Passonneau, 1988; Song & Cohen, 1991).

The given practice nowadays has been to compute some sort of transitive closure over the network/graph of constraints on temporal events (usually expressed in the well-known Allen algebra (Allen, 1983), or a sub-algebra), and then either to compare the sets of simple temporal relations that are deduced from it with standard precision and recall, or to measure the agreement between all relations, including disjunctions of information (Verhagen, Gaizauskas, Schilder, Hepple, Katz, & Pustejovsky, 2007).

Precision and recall evaluations are often not performed on graphs of relations between all events in a text however, but on the subproblem of ordering pairs of successively described events (Mani & Schiffman, 2005; Verhagen et al., 2007) or even same-sentence events (Lapata & Lascarides, 2006) (in our example, only e1 b e2 and e3 fi t1 1).
The main reason of this choice is the difficulty of the task, even for human beings, of assigning temporal relations in a large text (Setzer et al., 2006).
Exceptions exist, as in the work of Mani et al. (2006) and Mani et al.
Exceptions exist, as in the work of Mani et al. (2006) and Mani et al. (2007).
A constraint propagation algorithm ensures that all existing temporal relations are added to the network, labelling an inconsistency with ∅ (Allen, 1983).
A table of all composition rules in Allen algebra can be found in the work of Allen (1983) or Rodriguez et al.
A table of all composition rules in Allen algebra can be found in the work of Allen (1983) or Rodriguez et al. (2004), and a sample for a few basic relations is given in Table 2.

2 Time Point Algebra and Convex Relations Interval graphs can be converted easily into graphs between points (Vilain et al., 1990), where an event is split into a beginning and an ending point; the mapping between Allen relations and point relations is given at Table 1.
The relation between two time points is continuous if the assigned set of simple relations is convex (Vilain et al., 1990).

A so-called convex relation corresponds to cases where relations r1 to r4 are assigned to one of the 6 possible relations {<}, {<, =}, {=}, {<, =, >}, {>}, {>=}2, considered as conceptual neighbors (Freksa, 1992).
See the work by Schilder (1997) for a more complete presentation within a natural language processing perspective.
Similar measures have also been used during the TempEval evaluation campaign in 2007 (Verhagen et al., 2007), with a reduced set of relations : “before”, “overlaps” and “before or overlaps”.

Unfortunately, a unique minimal graph does not exist in the general case, and in particular for Allen relations. Rodriguez et al. (2004) propose a way to find all minimal graphs for a given temporal graph.

Unfortunately, a unique minimal graph does not exist in the general case, and in particular for Allen relations. Rodriguez et al. (2004) propose a way to find all minimal graphs for a given temporal graph. Their algorithm first finds core relations, relations that are in every minimal graph, by intersecting all derivations, and then computes all possible remaining combinations in order to find those composing a minimal graph. For example, for the relation RA,B between A and B, derivations are RA,C ◦RC,B , RA,D ◦RD,B , RA,E ◦RE,B , etc. If the intersection of all these derived relations equals RA,B , it means that RA,B is not a core relation, since it can be obtained by composing some other relations. Otherwise, the relation is a core relation, since removing it always leads to a loss of information. The way this “kernel” is obtained ensures its uniqueness. However, the second part of the procedure (compute remaining combinations) is computationally impractical, even for medium-sized graphs, since every subset of relations must be considered to determine a minimal graph on top of core relations. The authors do not detail much their empirical investigations, offering no support for the usability of this method. Moreover, it does not lead to a unique graph that could be compared to a reference. Going back to evaluation, Tannier and Muller (2008) suggest the comparison of graphs through core relations, which are easy to compute and give a good idea of how important the relations are in a same graph.
6 Behavior of Existing Metrics As stated in the work by Tannier and Muller (2008), a recall measure is expected to decrease in a linear way when the amount of information decreases.
The Figure presents an idealized case; more thorough experiments were done on the whole TimeBank corpus (Pustejovsky et al., 2003) and explained in details in Section 6.
Many similarity measures exist between two graphs once a many-to-many correspondence is found between the nodes of both graphs (Sorlin, 2006).

1 Transitive Reduction of Endpoint Graph To address the problem of finding minimal graphs and to take into account the relative importance of relations, we take inspiration from the work of Dubois and Schwer (2000) in two main ideas.
It is enough to prove that E(G) (or G) is the graph of a transitive, acyclic relation to prove that E(G) has a unique transitive reduction (Aho et al., 1972).

But in a relaxed scheme, with disjunctions, it becomes necessary to apply a weighting procedure; a response is no longer assigned a binary value (0 or 1), but for example one of the values in Table 3, in a manner similar to what was done in TempEval (Verhagen et al., 2007).

The temporal relations encode topological information between the time intervals of occurring eventualities, using relations that are equivalent to Allen relations, although they have different names. The TimeML standard specifies the relations between events, the anchoring of events to “times” (dates, hours) and the relations between times. There are about 7000 annotated relations between temporal entities. Additions to this set have been proposed (Bethard, Martin, & Klingenstein, 2007), in order to complete the annotations. As was noted by Setzer (2001), tagging temporal relations is hard for

In order to do so, we took an implementation of a temporal relation classifier reproducing standard work, as for instance in the work by Mani et al. (2006), that was used by one of the authors in another study (Denis & Muller, 2010).
The bulk of the work done on event relation classification deals primarily with extended intervals, as does the literature on temporal semantics (Steedman, 1997; Kamp & Reyle, 1993).
The few exceptions (Chambers & Jurafsky, 2008b; Bramsen et al., 2006) make use of subsets of relations, for instance a subset {before, after}, and any other relation is considered as “vague”.

metadata.abstractText: Temporal information has been the focus of recent attention in information extraction, leading to some standardization effort, in particular for the task of relating events in a text. This task raises the problem of comparing two annotations of a given text, because relations between events in a story are intrinsically interdependent and cannot be evaluated separately. A proper evaluation measure is also crucial in the context of a machine learning approach to the problem. Finding a common comparison referent at the text level is not obvious, and we argue here in favor of a shift from eventbased measures to measures on a unique textual object, a minimal underlying temporal graph, or more formally the transitive reduction of the graph of relations between event boundaries. We support it by an investigation of its properties on synthetic data and on a well-know temporal corpus.
